articles.headline: Star in New Role, Gore Revisits Old Stage
articles.snippet: Al Gore’s return to Capitol Hill on Wednesday is akin to a recovering alcoholic returning to a neighborhood bar.
articles.abstract: Al Gore’s return to Capitol Hill on Wednesday is akin to a recovering alcoholic returning to a neighborhood bar.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 20 — The last time Al Gore appeared publicly inside the United States Capitol, he was certifying the Electoral College victory of George W. Bush. He returns on Wednesday, a heartbreak loser turned Oscar boasting Nobel hopeful globe trotting multimillionaire pop culture eminence.
articles.byline: By Mark Leibovich and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: Aid to Palestinians Rose Despite an Embargo
articles.snippet: The U.S. and the Europe have led a boycott, but they provided more aid to the Palestinians in 2006 than 2005.
articles.abstract: The U.S. and the Europe have led a boycott, but they provided more aid to the Palestinians in 2006 than 2005.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, March 20 — Despite the international embargo on aid to the Palestinian Authority since Hamas came to power a year ago, significantly more aid was delivered to the Palestinians in 2006 than in 2005, according to official figures from the United Nations, United States, European Union and International Monetary Fund.

articles.headline: U.S. Cautions Foreign Companies on Iran Deals
articles.snippet: The Bush administration has been warning energy companies that penalties are possible if they pursue oil and gas deals with Iran.
articles.abstract: The Bush administration has been warning energy companies that penalties are possible if they pursue oil and gas deals with Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 20 — For all its efforts to apply economic and political pressure on Iran over its nuclear program, the United States has never used a potentially potent tool in its arsenal — penalties on foreign companies that assist Iran in producing oil and natural gas.

articles.headline: Inside Japan’s Puzzle Palace
articles.snippet: If there is another puzzle craze after sudoku, chances are it will spring from a Japanese company called Nikoli.
articles.abstract: If there is another puzzle craze after sudoku, chances are it will spring from a Japanese company called Nikoli.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, March 20 — Will there be another puzzle craze after sudoku?

articles.headline: Blockbuster Chief Agrees to Exit Deal
articles.snippet: Differences between John F. Antioco and the company’s board over his compensation package have dragged on for nearly two years.
articles.abstract: Differences between John F. Antioco and the company’s board over his compensation package have dragged on for nearly two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: John F. Antioco, the chief executive of Blockbuster who has been locked in a dispute with company directors over the size of his bonus, has agreed to leave his job at the end of the year.

articles.headline: Doctors’ Ties to Drug Makers Are Put on Close View
articles.snippet: Minnesota records provide a window on the financial ties between drug companies and the doctors who prescribe their products.
articles.abstract: Minnesota records provide a window on the financial ties between drug companies and the doctors who prescribe their products.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Allan Collins may be the most influential kidney specialist in the country. He is president of the National Kidney Foundation and director of a government-financed research center on kidney disease.
articles.byline: By Gardiner Harris and Janet Roberts

articles.headline: Bush Clashes With Congress on Prosecutors
articles.snippet: The president and Congress appeared headed toward a showdown over demands for White House documents and advisers’ testimony.
articles.abstract: The president and Congress appeared headed toward a showdown over demands for White House documents and advisers’ testimony.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 20 — President Bush and Congress clashed Tuesday over an inquiry into the firing of federal prosecutors and appeared headed toward a constitutional showdown over demands from Capitol Hill for internal White House documents and testimony from top advisers to the president.

articles.headline: Once Again, Debt Is Miscast as the Villain
articles.snippet: Americans seem to take on more of it than any other society, but, boy, do we like to beat ourselves up about it.
articles.abstract: Americans seem to take on more of it than any other society, but, boy, do we like to beat ourselves up about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Later this year, the National Film Preservation Foundation is going to re-release a silent movie from 1912 called “The Usurer’s Grip.” It’s a cautionary tale about borrowed money that revolves around the Jenkses, a fictional middle-class family who need a $25 loan so their young daughter can be treated for consumption. After a loan shark tricks Mr. Jenks into borrowing at an interest rate of 180 percent, the family is brought to the brink of ruin.

articles.headline: Trial Begins for Ex-Chief of Hollinger
articles.snippet: Two different portraits of Conrad M. Black were presented in opening arguments at the criminal trial against the former newspaper baron.
articles.abstract: Two different portraits of Conrad M. Black were presented in opening arguments at the criminal trial against the former newspaper baron.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, March 20 — Two wildly different portraits of Conrad M. Black were presented to the jury in opening arguments Tuesday at the criminal trial against the former newspaper baron and three colleagues.
